definition[0]: to make a job less important, or to move someone to a less important job
definition[1]: to make something seem less important or valuable than it is
example[0]: Police often downgrade the seriousness of violence against women in the home.
definition[2]: to state that something is not as serious as it was
example[1]: Hurricane Bob has been downgraded to a tropical storm.
definition[3]: to give something less importance, for example by spending less money on it or reducing its value
example[2]: The drug company is planning to downgrade some of its products from prescription status.
definition[4]: to make someone’s job less important or well-paid than it was before
example[3]: Eighty-eight middle managers had been made redundant, downgraded or fired.
example[4]: Services have been reduced and temporary contracts are being used to downgrade or replace qualified staff.
definition[5]: to reduce an amount or value that you had calculated or guessed
example[5]: Analysts downgraded four-year profit projections and exposed the fledgling company to the harsher side of stockmarket life.
example[6]: The company’s long-term debt-rating has been downgraded from triple-A to double-A-2.
